chapter.htmlHeader: When should I refer a person with hearing loss to secondary care?
chapter.summary: Covers when a patient with hearing loss should be referred to secondary care.
chapter.htmlStringContent: From age 18 years onwards.

chapters.fullItemName: Have I got the right topic?

subChapters.htmlHeader: When should I refer a person with hearing loss to secondary care?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
Refer immediately (for assessment within 24 hours by ENT or an emergency department) anyone presenting with:

  • Sudden onset (over 3 days or less) unilateral or bilateral hearing loss which has occurred within the past 30 days and cannot be explained by external or middle ear causes.
  • Unilateral hearing loss associated with focal neurology (such as altered sensation or facial droop).
    • If stroke is suspected follow a local stroke referral pathway. For more information, see the CKS topic on Stroke and TIA.
  • Hearing loss associated with head or neck injury.
    • For further information, see the CKS topic on Head injury.
  • Hearing loss associated with severe infection such as necrotising otitis externa or Ramsay Hunt syndrome.
    • Otalgia and otorrhoea that has not responded to treatment within 72 hours in a person who is immuno-compromised is suggestive of necrotising otitis externa.
    • For more information on Ramsay Hunt syndrome, see the CKS topic on Shingles.

Refer to be seen urgently (within 2 weeks) anyone presenting with:

  • Sudden onset (over 3 days or less) unilateral or bilateral hearing loss which developed more than 30 days ago and cannot be explained by external or middle ear causes.
    • Refer to ENT or an audiovestibular medicine service.
  • Rapidly progressive hearing loss (over a period of 4–90 days) which cannot be explained by external or middle ear causes.
    • Refer to ENT or an audiovestibular medicine service.
  • Suspected head and neck malignancy — refer using a 2 week cancer pathway.
    • Consider nasopharyngeal carcinoma in adults presenting with hearing loss and middle ear effusion (especially unilateral) which is not associated with an upper respiratory tract infection.
    • Consider malignant tumours of the external ear in people presenting with bloody discharge.
    • For more information, see the CKS topic on Head and neck cancers - recognition and referral.

Refer routinely to ENT or audiovestibular medicine (using a local pathway) anyone presenting with hearing loss (not explained by acute external or middle ear causes) and:

  • Unilateral or asymmetric gradual onset hearing loss as their main symptom.
    • Consider causes such as vestibular schwannoma, CPA tumour, cholesteatoma or otosclerosis.
  • Fluctuating hearing loss that is not associated with an upper respiratory tract infection.
    • Consider causes such as Meniere’s disease and fluctuating middle ear effusion (be aware that this can be linked with nasopharyngeal tumours).
  • Hearing loss associated with hyperacusis.
  • Hearing loss associated with persistent tinnitus which is:
    • Unilateral — unilateral tinnitus can be caused by conditions such as vestibular schwannoma, Meniere’s disease or otosclerosis.
    • Pulsatile — pulsatile tinnitus can be caused by intracranial vascular tumours, aneurysms, carotid atherosclerosis or brainstem pathology.
    • Significantly changed (excluding other reasons for change such as ear wax or infection) — change in character of tinnitus may be associated with anxiety or stress but can also be associated with progressive pathology such as cholesteatoma.
    • Causing distress — investigation of underlying cause and management by a specialist is indicated.
  • Hearing loss associated with persistent or recurrent vertigo.
    • Specialist assessment to identify underlying cause (for example Meniere’s disease, perilymph fistula, CPA tumour or brainstem pathology) is indicated.
  • Hearing loss that is not age related.
    • If assessment suggests hearing loss is not age related referral for further investigation is indicated to identify underlying causes (such as genetic, infective, autoimmune, renal or neurological conditions and exposure to ototoxic drugs or chemicals).

Consider referring (to an audiology service) all adults at risk of having or developing hearing loss who have limited ability to seek help and in whom hearing loss might otherwise be missed, including people with:

  • Diagnosed dementia or mild cognitive impairment — consider hearing assessment every 2 years if not previously diagnosed with hearing loss.
  • Suspected dementia – hearing loss may be a co-morbid condition or misinterpreted as increasing cognitive decline.
  • Diagnosed learning disability — refer when the person transfers from child to adult services and subsequently every 2 years.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
The recommendations on when to refer a person with hearing loss to an ear, nose and throat (ENT) specialist, emergency department or audiovestibular medicine service are based on the National Institute of Health and Care Excellence (NICE) clinical guideline Hearing loss in adults: assessment and management [NICE, 2018], guidance from the British Academy of Audiology [British Academy of Audiology, 2016] and expert opinion in review articles [Stachler, 2012; Edmiston, 2013; Phan, 2016]  [Cunningham, 2017; BMJ Best Practice, 2018; Fishman, 2018; Michels, 2019].

  • Timeliness of referral
    • Indications for immediate, urgent and routine referral are taken from the NICE clinical guideline Hearing loss in adults: assessment and management [NICE, 2018]. The majority of cases of hearing loss will have no identifiable cause or specific treatment but clinicians must be aware of features suggestive of life-threatening or treatable causes — prompt diagnosis and treatment may prevent or limit morbidity [Stachler, 2012; Fishman, 2018; NICE, 2018].
  • Immediate referral (same day):
    • Sudden hearing loss (occurring over 72 hours or less) which has developed within the past 30 days is an acute ontological emergency. Treatable causes include autoimmune disease, chronic infection, vestibular schwannoma and stroke — early intervention may significantly improve outcome [British Academy of Audiology, 2016; Fishman, 2018; NICE, 2019].
    • Unilateral hearing loss on the same side as altered sensation of the face or facial droop may indicate a vestibular schwannoma or cerebellopontine angle (CPA) tumour, a viral infection, aggressive cholesteatoma or stroke [NICE, 2018].
    • Persistent otalgia and otorrhoea in people with diabetes or immunocompromise is suggestive of necrotising otitis externa (previously known as malignant otitis externa) where otitis externa infection extends inwards affecting the skull base and cranial nerves. This is a life-threatening condition and early identification and appropriate treatment is essential [NICE, 2018].
  • Urgent referral (to be seen within 2 weeks):
    • NICE recommend that for sudden hearing loss which developed over 30 days ago urgent investigation is still required but immediate care is not [NICE, 2019].
    • Unilateral or bilateral hearing loss which is rapidly worsening over a period of 4–90 days and cannot be explained by external or middle ear causes may indicate autoimmune disease, chronic infection, vestibular schwannoma or intracranial tumours [NICE, 2018; NICE, 2019].
    • Unilateral persistent middle ear effusion not associated with upper respiratory tract infection in people of Chinese and South-East Asian family origin may indicate nasopharyngeal carcinoma. Incidence is higher in these groups (positive predictive value of 3% or above) and other racial groups such as those from North Africa and Eskimos. Nasopharyngeal carcinoma is generally less common in people of European family origin. Early recognition and treatment is associated with much better outcome [NICE, 2018].
  • Routine referral
    • Unilateral or asymmetric hearing loss unrelated to earwax or an acute external or middle ear infection may indicate conditions such as vestibular schwannoma or CPA tumour, cholesteatoma or otosclerosis — NICE recommend routine referral unless hearing loss is sudden or rapidly progressive or accompanied by localising clinical features [NICE, 2018].
    • Persistent tinnitus associated with hearing loss should be referred for further investigation — NICE advise that transient tinnitus (lasting for periods of less than 5 minutes) or which occurs after significant noise exposure or with upper respiratory tract infections or earwax occlusion does not require diagnostic referral [NICE, 2018].
  • Referral for audiological assessment for adults at risk of having or developing hearing loss who have limited ability to seek help
    • Guidance from NICE [NICE, 2018] and NHS England [NHS England, 2017] recommend considering assessment for and monitoring of hearing loss in people with cognitive impairment or learning disability — recommendations are based on consensus opinion [NICE, 2018].
    • Unidentified hearing loss can significantly affect understanding and social interactions and exacerbate underlying cognitive difficulties. This may contribute to increasing confusion and withdrawal and be misinterpreted as worsening cognitive decline rather than treatable hearing impairment [NICE, 2018]. In addition, hearing loss often co-exists with dementia and if not addressed can accelerate cognitive decline [NHS England, 2017].
    • People with mild cognitive impairment, dementia or learning disabilities may not be aware of their hearing loss or may not have the capacity to ask for help hearing loss. It is important to establish a baseline and retest regularly [NICE, 2018].
